{{lang|ta|இலங்கை கணக்காய்வாளர் தலைமை}} | insignia = File:Auditor General's Dept SL logo.png | insigniasize = 125px | insigniacaption = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | incumbent = [[Gamini Wijesinghe]] | incumbentsince = 27 November 2015 | type = | status = | department = [[Auditor-General's Department of Sri Lanka|Auditor-General's Department]] | style = | member_of = | reports_to = | residence = | seat = 306/72 Polduwa road, [[Battaramulla]] | nominator = The [[President of Sri Lanka|President]] | appointer = The [[President of Sri Lanka|President]] | appointer_qualified = with [[Constitutional Council (Sri Lanka)|Constitutional Council]] [[advice and consent]] | termlength = | termlength_qualified = | constituting_instrument = | precursor = | formation = {{Start date and age|1799|01|24}} | first = [[Cecil Smith (Auditor General)|Cecil Smith]]
(as Accountant and Auditor General) | last = | abolished = | succession = | abbreviation = | unofficial_names = | deputy = | salary = | website = {{URL|auditorgeneral.gov.lk}} }} The '''Auditor General of Sri Lanka''' ([[Sinhalese language|Sinhala]]: ශ්‍රී ලංකා විගණකාධිපති ''Śrī Laṃkā viganakādhipathi''; [[Tamil language|Tamil]]: இலங்கை கணக்காய்வாளர் தலைமை) is appointed by the [[President of Sri Lanka|President]] to aid [[accountability]] by conducting independent [[financial audit|audit]]s of government operations. These audits provide members of [[Parliament of Sri Lanka|Parliament]] with objective information to help them examine the government's activities and hold it to account. According to the [[Constitution of Sri Lanka|constitution]], the Auditor General is empowered to audit the accounts of all departments of Government, the Offices of the Cabinet of Ministers, the Judicial Service Commission, the Public Service Commission, the Parliamentary Commissioner for Administration, the Secretary-General of Parliament and the Commissioner of Elections, local authorities, public corporations and business or other undertakings vested in the Government under any written law.{{citaiton needed|date=November 2017}} The Auditor General of Sri Lanka is the head of the [[Auditor General's Department (Sri Lanka)|Auditor General's Department]].{{cite web|title=The Auditor General’s Role and Responsibilities|url=http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=107&Itemid=54&lang=en|publisher=auditorgeneral.gov.lk|accessdate=13 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=Former Auditor Generals|url=http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=88&Itemid=56&lang=en|publisher=auditorgeneral.gov.lk|accessdate=13 December 2013}}{{cite web|title=History of the Auditor General's Department|url=http://www.auditorgeneral.gov.lk/web/images/aboutus/HistoryoftheAuditorGeneralsDepartment.pdf|website=auditorgeneral.gov.lk|publisher=Auditor General's Department|accessdate=3 November 2017}} ==List of Auditors General== While the title of ''Auditor General of Sri Lanka'' was formally adopted on the country's enactment of its [[Constitution of Sri Lanka|1978 republican constitution]], the position or an equivalent to it has existed since 1799 under various titles. The Department in its current form considers itself a continuation of the office established in 1799, and the table below thus lists all officeholders that have held positions equivalent to the position of the current Auditor General.

[[Alpine skiing combined|Combined]] |club = |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1957|01|03|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Kranj]], [[SFR Yugoslavia]] |height = |wcdebut = 10 December 1976 |retired = 26 March 1988 |website = |olympicteams = |olympicmedals = 0 |olympicgolds = 0 |worldsteams = |worldsmedals = 1 |worldsgolds = 0 |wcseasons = 12 |wcwins = 8 |wcpodiums = 33 |wcoveralls = 0 |wctitles = 1 |medals = {{MedalSport|Men's [[alpine skiing]]}} {{MedalCountry|{{YUG}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalSilver|[[Alpine World Ski Championships 1982|1982 Schladming]]|Slalom}} }} '''Bojan Križaj''' ({{audio|Sl-Bojan Križaj.oga|listen}}) (born 3 January 1957) is a Slovenian, back then Yugoslavian, former [[alpine skier]]. During his international career he competed for the then-existing [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]]. He competed at three Winter Olympics.{{cite Sports-Reference |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/kr/bojan-krizaj-1.html |title=Bojan Križaj Olympic Results |accessdate=19 March 2018}} ==Career== Križaj, born in [[Kranj]], was a member of a well known [[Tržič]] ski family so he started skiing at the age of 3. In the season 1976/77 he received the first World Cup point, qualified among the 15 best [[Slalom skiing|slalom]] runners and later during that season in [[Madonna di Campiglio]] he hit his first top 3 podium. On 20 January 1980 he achieved the first [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslav]] World Cup victory in [[Wengen, Switzerland|Wengen]], [[Switzerland]] and later he won seven more times, thus still being Yugoslavia's and Slovenia's most successful male alpine skier to date. At [[1980 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lake Placid, New York]], [[United States|U.S.]], he reached the fourth place in [[giant slalom]], missing the bronze medal by only two hundredths of second. Four years later he took the [[Olympic Oath|athlete's oath]] at the opening ceremony for [[Sarajevo]]'s [[1984 Winter Olympics]]. He caused a stir when he spoke the oath not in [[Croatian or Serbian]] but in [[Slovene language|Slovene]]. Despite great expectations of the Yugoslav audience he finished ninth in [[giant slalom]], much less than expected. Križaj should also have competed at [[1988 Winter Olympics]] in [[Calgary|Calgary, Alberta]], [[Canada]], but he got injured a few days before the event. His most successful World Championship was in 1982 in [[Schladming]], [[Austria]] where he received the silver medal in [[Slalom skiing|slalom]]. His most successful World Cup season was 1986/87 when he received the small crystal globe for the season's best slalom runner (that was the only men's crystal globe of that season not won by [[Pirmin Zurbriggen]]). Beside that he was the second in World Cup slalom standings in the 1979/80 and 1985/86 seasons and third in the 1980/81 season. His best position in overall World Cup standings was the 4th place in 1979/80. He concluded his career in 1988 at the race in [[Saalbach-Hinterglemm|Saalbach]], [[Austria]] where he stepped off the skis right at the end of the track and walked into the finish area. Since his skiing retirement he worked in many fields, including as importer of Austrian brand beer and adviser for ski products in [[Elan Line|Elan]] company. {{other uses}} {{Infobox company | name = Butterball LLC | logo = Butterball Logo.jpg | logo_size = 200px | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = 2006 | location = [[Garner, North Carolina]], [[United States|U.S.]] | key_people = Kerry Doughty, President and CEO | num_employees = 5500<ref name=Smithfield/> | industry = Poultry | products = [[turkey meat|Turkey]] | revenue = $1.5 billion (2008) | operating_income = | net_income = | owner =Maxwell Farms and [[Seaboard Corporation]] | homepage = [http://www.butterball.com/ Butterball] }}
'''Butterball''' is a [[brand]] of [[turkey meat|turkey]] and other [[poultry]] products produced by Butterball LLC. The company manufactures food products in the United States and internationally — specializing in turkey, cured deli meats, raw roasts and specialty products such as soups and salads, sandwiches, and entrées.
'''Butterball LLC''' was a [[joint venture]] of [[Smithfield Foods]] and [[Maxwell Farms Inc.]],<ref>[http://www.smithfieldfoods.com/Investor/Press/press_view.asp?ID=354 Smithfield Foods::Investor Information::Press Releases<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> an affiliate of the Goldsboro Milling Co.<ref name="titan">{{cite web | title = Butterball acquisition creates a turkey titan | publisher = Refrigerated Transporter, Oct 4, 2006 | url = http://refrigeratedtrans.com/news/Carolina-Turkeys-acquires-Butterball/index.html?imw=Y}}</ref> [[Seaboard Corporation]] bought Smithfield's stake in Butterball in 2010. The company sells over one billion pounds of turkey a year.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} Though the ''Butterball'' brand has been formally recognized since 1940, Butterball LLC was formed in 2006.
In Canada, the rights to Butterball are owned by Exceldor Foods Ltd.
==Products== According to Butterball, the following products are sold under the Butterball name:<ref>[http://www.butterball.com/en/main_canvas.jsp?includePage=product_home.jsp&t=Products%20Landing%20Page&s0=products&s1= Turkey Products|Butterball] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061117162328/http://www.butterball.com/en/main_canvas.jsp?includePage=product_home.jsp&t=Products%20Landing%20Page&s0=products&s1= |date=November 17, 2006 }}</ref>
{{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} *whole turkeys *turkey cuts *[[cold cut]]s *[[sausage]] *[[turkey bacon]] {{Col-break}} *turkey medallions, strips, chicken strips *turkey franks *ground turkey *frozen turkey burgers, mignons, meatballs {{Col-break}}
{{col-end}}
Among numerous other brands, [[England|English]]-bred Butterball turkeys are sold in the [[United Kingdom]] during [[Christmas]] time for the Christmas [[Christmas dinner#United Kingdom|feast]].
==History== [[Image:Butterball plant, Longmont, CO IMG 5214.JPG|200px|right|thumb|The Butterball plant in downtown [[Longmont, Colorado|Longmont]], [[Colorado]]]]
The name Butterball was originally registered as trademark #378,438 on June 11, 1940, by Ada Walker of [[Wyoming, Ohio|Wyoming]], [[Ohio]]. Leo Peters purchased the trademark in February 1951. Leo Peters licensed the name to [[JBS USA|Swift and Co.]] for 10 years before selling it in the 1960s. Peters sold the name "Butterball" to Swift, which was acquired by [[ConAgra]] in 1990.
Leo Peters retained rights to use the name '''Butterball Farms''' for his butter products<ref name="retained">{{cite web |title=Butterball Farms, History |publisher=Butterball Farms, History |url=http://butterballfarms.com/Our_History.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708105209/http://butterballfarms.com/Our_History.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }}</ref> and the company operates today as Butterball Farms, Inc., producing and marketing shaped [[butter]] products.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928225218/http://www.butterballfarms.com/foodservice/products2.php Butterball Farms product page]</ref>
In October 2006, ConAgra's Butterball branded turkey business was sold to [[North Carolina]]-based '''Carolina Turkeys,''' making Carolina Turkey the largest turkey producer in the United States.<ref name="largest">{{cite news | title = Carolina Turkey gobbles up Butterball for $325M | publisher = Triangle Business Journal, October 2, 2006 | url = http://triangle.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2006/10/02/daily9.html | date=October 2, 2006}}</ref> The company, located southeast of Raleigh, NC in [[Mount Olive, North Carolina]] on the Wayne and Duplin county line, subsequently renamed itself Butterball LLC.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/food/2006-11-21-butterball_x.htm USA Today: Sale of Butterball turkey business not expected to change Thanksgiving icon]</ref>
In 2008, the company moved its headquarters to a new $12 million building in Greenfield North off Interstate 40 in [[Garner, North Carolina]]. The headquarters has a "customer experience center" with a special kitchen for promotional demonstrations.<ref name="major deal">{{cite news | title = A major deal that was no turkey | publisher = Triangle Business Journal, November 16, 2007 | url = http://triangle.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2007/11/19/tidbits2.html | date=November 19, 2007}}</ref>
Smithfield offered $200 million to Maxwell Farms for the portion of Butterball that Smithfield did not own. Chief executive C. Larry Pope said at that time that he hoped Maxwell Farms would spend more on the company's facilities and marketing. A decision had to be made whether to buy Maxwell's share or sell Smithfield's. On September 10, 2010, Smithfield announced the sale of its 49 percent share of Butterball for an estimated $175 million. Maxwell Farms will sell 50 percent of Butterball to Seaboard Corp.<ref name=Smithfield>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2010/09/10/673672/smithfield-to-sell-its-stake-in.html|title=Smithfield to sell its stake in Butterball|last=Felberbaum|first=Michael|work=[[News & Observer]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=2010-09-10|accessdate=2010-09-10}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Corporate== Walter “Gator” Pelletier, past chairman of the [[National Turkey Federation]], is Butterball LLC's corporate secretary — managing all operating activities from turkey production and directing Maxwell Farms, the managing partner of Butterball. Pelletier is also president of Maxwell Farms, Inc., vice president of Goldsboro Milling Company, and secretary-treasurer of Maxwell Foods, Inc. Pelletier had joined Goldsboro Milling Company in 1981.<ref name="major deal-2">{{cite web |title=NTF Chairman Says Change in Attitude Will be Needed to Address Numerous Issues |publisher=Eatturnkey.com, National Turkey Federation, February 7, 2009 |url=http://www.eatturkey.com/news/news_detail.cgi/194/0 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130121184504/http://www.eatturkey.com/news/news_detail.cgi/194/0 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-21 |df= }}</ref>
==Turkey Talk-Line== Beginning in late 1981, Butterball has maintained a toll-free telephone line called the Turkey Talk-Line to help customers with cooking and preparation questions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/butterballs-turkey-hotline-has-been-preventing-thanksgiving-disasters-35-years-174358/ |publisher=Ad Week |title=Butterball’s Turkey Hotline Has Been Preventing Thanksgiving Disasters for 35 Years |date=November 1, 2016 |author=Robert Klara}}</ref> Eleven thousand people called in 1981, and in recent years the number has grown to over 200,000 each holiday season. The most frequent question asked is how long a turkey takes to defrost.
In ''[[The West Wing]]'' episode "[[The Indians in the Lobby]]", President [[Josiah Bartlet]] calls the number (referred to as the "Butterball Hotline" in the script) to discuss stuffing and cooking his Thanksgiving turkey.
==Criticism== Animal welfare activists such as [[Mercy for Animals]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Free Animal Video|title=Butterball Turkey Animal Cruelty Undercover Video MFA|date=2014-04-25|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bhi-Gg2b46A|accessdate=2016-11-13}}</ref> the [[Humane Society of the United States]], and [[PETA]] have accused Butterball of animal cruelty.<ref name="butterballabuse">{{cite web |url=http://butterballabuse.com/ |title=Butterball Abuse |date=December 28, 2011 |publisher=Mercy for Animals |accessdate=December 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peta.org/features/butterball-peta-investigation.aspx|title=Butterball's House of Horrors: A PETA Undercover Investigation |date=2010-10-21|accessdate=December 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.humanesociety.org/news/press_releases/2009/12/shareholder_resolution_urges.html |title=Shareholder Resolution Urges Smithfield to Help Decrease Suffering of Butterball Turkeys |date=December 22, 2009 |publisher=Humane Society of the United States |accessdate=December 29, 2011}}</ref> These organizations cite intentional cruelty inflicted on the birds, as well as the incidental cruelty inherent in the slaughter methods used, and the breeding practices which produce animals too large to reproduce without human intervention.
In October 2012, a Mercy for Animals investigator documented a pattern of abuse and neglect at numerous Butterball turkey operations in North Carolina. The investigation revealed workers kicking and stomping on birds, dragging them by their wings and necks, and throwing turkeys onto the ground or on top of other birds; birds suffering from serious untreated illnesses and injuries, including open sores, infections, and broken bones; and workers grabbing birds by their wings or necks and violently slamming them into tiny transport crates with no regard for their welfare.<ref>{{cite web|title=Butterball Abuse: Undercover Investigation Exposes Shocking Cruelty...Again!|url=http://www.butterballabuse.com/|publisher=Mercy For Animals}}</ref>
This investigation occurred less than one year after a Mercy for Animals undercover investigation into a different Butterball turkey facility led to five workers being charged with criminal [[cruelty to animals]]. Mercy for Animals’ 2011 investigation at a Butterball turkey factory farm in Shannon, Hoke County, North Carolina revealed Butterball workers violently kicking and stomping on birds, dragging them by their wings and necks, slamming them into transport crates, and leaving turkeys to suffer from serious untreated injuries and infections.<ref>{{cite web|title=Butterball Abuse|url=http://www.butterballabuse.com/|publisher=Mercy For Animals|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref> As a result of the investigation, North Carolina officials raided the facility and arrested several employees.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galli|first=Cindy|title=Butterball Turkey Raided Amid Animal Abuse Allegations|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/butterball-turkey-raided-amid-animal-abuse-allegations/story?id=15249456#.Tvyp6lb4WSo|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref>
In August 2012, Butterball worker Brian Douglas pleaded guilty to felony cruelty to animals—marking the first-ever felony conviction for cruelty to factory-farmed birds in United States history.<ref>{{cite web|last=Runkle|first=Nathan|title=Making History: Butterball Case Marks First-Ever Felony Conviction for Cruelty to Factory-Farmed Birds|url=http://www.mfablog.org/2012/08/making-history-butterball-conviction-marks-first-ever-felony-conviction-for-cruelty-to-factory-farme.html|publisher=Mercy For Animals|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Winter|first=Michael|title=Ex-N.C. turkey farm worker pleads guilty to animal cruelty|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2012/08/nc-turkey-farm-worker-pleads-guilty-to-animal-cruelty/1|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=5 September 2012|date=28 August 2012}}</ref> Several days later, another Butterball employee, Rueben Mendoza, pleaded guilty to misdemeanor cruelty to animals and felony identity theft.<ref>{{cite web|title=Breaking News: Another Butterball Worker Pleads Guilty to Cruelty to Animals|url=http://www.mfablog.org/2012/08/breaking-news-another-butterball-worker-pleads-guilty-to-cruelty-to-animals.html|publisher=Mercy For Animals|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref>
In February 2013, two more Butterball workers, Terry Johnson and Billy McBride, were found guilty of misdemeanor animal cruelty as a result of MFA's investigation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Runkle|first=Nathan|title=Breaking News: Two More Butterball Workers Convicted of Cruelty to Animals|url=http://www.mfablog.org/2013/02/breaking-news-two-more-butterball-workers-convicted-of-cruelty-to-animals.html|publisher=Mercy For Animals|accessdate=23 February 2013}}</ref>
In addition to the felony and misdemeanor cruelty convictions, MFA’s investigation at Butterball uncovered government corruption. Dr. Sarah Jean Mason, the director of Animal Health Programs with the North Carolina Department of Agriculture, was arrested and pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice charges after admitting to warning Butterball about the raid by law enforcement and potentially compromising the criminal cruelty investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=More animal cruelty arrests at Butterball facility in Hoke County|url=http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2012/feb/17/more-animal-cruelty-arrests-at-butterball-facility-ar-1941598/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130127152549/http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2012/feb/17/more-animal-cruelty-arrests-at-butterball-facility-ar-1941598/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=27 January 2013|publisher=Winston-Salem Journal|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref>

'''Christian Ancher''' (27 July 1711 – 9 January 1765) was a Norwegian merchant, timber trader and ship owner.<ref name=nbl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=|title=Christian Ancher |encyclopedia=[[Norsk biografisk leksikon]]|first=Odd Arvid |last=Storsveen |editor=[[Knut Helle|Helle, Knut]] |publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo |url=http://www.snl.no/.nbl_biografi/Christian_Ancher/utdypning |language=Norwegian|accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>
==Biography== Ancher was born in [[Søndre Land]] in [[Oppland]], Norway. He was the son of Bernt Ancher (1680–1724) and Karen Tanche (1685–1758). The son of a vicar in the [[Church of Norway]], he trained in the trading house established by cousins [[James Collett]] (1655–1727) and Peder Leuch (1692–1746) in [[Oslo|Christiania]] (now Oslo).<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.collettfamilyhistory.net/The%20Norway%20Colletts%20-%20A%20Brief%20Business%20Summary.htm|title= The Merchant Patriciate of Christiania |publisher= collettfamilyhistory |author= John Peter Collett |accessdate= June 30, 2016}}</ref> He eventually became the largest [[timber trade]]r in Christiania. He was also quite active in shipping. He is commonly associated with his residence [[Paléet]] Manor near [[Bjørvika]], which later was used as a Royal residence.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Paléet |encyclopedia=[[Oslo byleksikon]] |editor1=Arstal, Aksel|editor1-link=Aksel Arstal |editor2=[[Carl Just|Just, Carl]] |publisher=Aschehoug |location=Oslo|edition=2|year=1966 |origyear=1938 |language=Norwegian }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|first=Ludvig|last=Daae |authorlink=Ludvig Ludvigsen Daae |title=Det gamle Christiania 1624–1814|edition=2 |year=1891|language=Norwegian|publisher=Cappelen|location=Christiania|pages=254–256}}</ref>
==Personal life== He was married to Karen Elieson (1723–1806). They were the parents of four sons: [[Bernt Anker]] who was a merchant and owner of [[Frogner Manor]], [[Peder Anker]] who became Prime Minister of Norway and was owner of [[Bogstad|Bogstad Manor]] as well as Iver (1745–1772) and Jess (1753–1798).<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia|title=Christian Ancher |encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor-last=Godal | editor-first=Anne Marit | editor-link=Anne Marit Godal |publisher=Norsk nettleksikon|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/Christian_Ancher|language=Norwegian|accessdate=29 January 2012}}</ref>

70,000 with Collins | parent = [[United Technologies]] | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = [https://www.collinsaerospace.com collinsaerospace.com] | footnotes = }} '''Collins Aerospace''', a [[United Technologies]] subsidiary, is one of the world’s largest suppliers of aerospace and defense products, headquartered in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]. == History == UTC Aerospace Systems (UTAS) was formed in August 2012 when parent [[United Technologies Corporation]] merged their existing subsidiary [[Hamilton Sundstrand]] with the newly acquired [[Goodrich Corporation]]. On 26 November 2018, United Technologies announced the completion of its [[Rockwell Collins]] acquisition, after which it merged its newly acquired business with UTC Aerospace Systems to form Collins Aerospace. The new company reported $23 billion of combined sales in 2017 and is composed of 70,000 employees.{{cite press release |url= http://www.utc.com/News/News-Center/Pages/United-Technologies-Announces-Intention-to-Separate-Into-Three-Independent-Compan.aspx |title= United Technologies [...] Completes Acquisition of Rockwell Collins |date= November 26, 2018 |publisher= United Technologies}} ==Products== [[File:UTC Aerospace Systems.svg|thumb|Company logo used 2012-2018]] Collins Aerospace is engaged in designing, manufacturing and servicing systems and components for commercial, regional, business and military aircraft, helicopters and other platforms. Collins Aerospace is also a major supplier to international space programs. Collins Aerospace has two main segments: Aircraft Systems and Power, Control & Sensing Systems. These segments are then broken down into several business units. The Aircraft Systems consists of Actuation & Propeller Systems, Aerostructures, Air Management Systems, Interiors, and Landing Systems (formerly Landing Gear and Wheels and Brakes).[http://utcaerospacesystems.com/about/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128131649/http://utcaerospacesystems.com/about/ |date=January 28, 2013 }} The Power, Control & Sensing Systems consists of Electric Systems, Engine Systems, ISR & Space Systems, and Sensors & Integrated Systems.{{cite web|url=http://utcaerospacesystems.com/Company/Pages/company.aspx |title=Our Company |publisher=UTC Aerospace Systems |date= |accessdate=2014-03-15}} Collins Aerospace is the owner of Ithaco Space Systems, Inc., formerly owned by [[Goodrich Company]]. Ithaco produced items for the field of satellite control since 1962, such as Earth sensors, [[Reaction wheel|reaction/momentum wheels]], magnetometers and magnetic torquers.{{cite web|title=Attitude Control|url=http://spinoff.nasa.gov/spinoff1997/t2.html|publisher=NASA Spinoff|accessdate=20 August 2013}} In addition to over 100 U.S. satellites, equipment made by Ithaco flew on Japanese, Canadian, French, German, Spanish, Swedish, and Argentinean spacecraft. Ithaco became notable for having manufactured the reaction wheels of the [[Kepler (spacecraft)|Kepler spacecraft]], the [[Hayabusa|Hayabusa spacecraft]], the Mesosphere Energetics and Dynamics (TIMED) satellite and the [[Dawn (spacecraft)|Dawn spacecraft]], which developed problems or even failed.{{cite web|last=Cowen|first=Ron|title=The wheels come off Kepler|url=http://www.nature.com/news/the-wheels-come-off-kepler-1.13032|publisher=Nature.com|accessdate=18 August 2013}} The [[ROSAT]] reaction wheels lasted over 8 years. Collins Aerospace announced in August 2012 layoffs at Ithaco Space Systems due to Ithaco having been "focused on space programs that have recently seen slower growth", and further layoffs at former Hamilton Sundstrand.{{cite web|title=Layoffs At UTC Aerospace Systems — Former Hamilton Sunstrand|url=http://connecticut.cbslocal.com/2012/08/23/layoffs-at-utc-aerospace-systems-former-hamilton-sunstrand/|publisher=CBS Connecticut|accessdate=18 August 2013}} ==See also== * [[List of aircraft propeller manufacturers]] * [[LucasVarity]] * [[Pratt & Whitney]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.collinsaerospace.com Collins Aerospace website] * [http://utcaerospacesystems.com UTC Aerospace Systems website] {{UTC Aerospace Systems}} {{United Technologies Corporation}} [[Category:Aerospace companies of the United States]] [[Category:United Technologies Corporation]] [[Category:Rocket engine manufacturers]] [[Category:Windsor Locks, Connecticut]] [[Category:Aircraft propeller manufacturers]] [[Category:Aircraft undercarriage manufacturers]] [[Category:Companies based in Charlotte, North Carolina]] {{Business-stub}}

{{Infobox award | name = Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe | image = | imagesize = 180px | caption = | description = Fastest time over a measured distance (time trial) | presenter = Aéro-Club de France | country = International | reward = | year = 1909 | year2 = 1936 | website = }}
The '''Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe''' was an international aeronautical speed competition instituted on 25 August 1909 by the French oil magnate [[Henry Deutsch de la Meurthe]]. The race was reinstated three times through the years at the initiative of the [[Aéro-Club de France]], and later by Deutsch de la Meurthe's widow Suzanne.
==First Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe== Announced in 1906, the first Deutsch de la Meurthe competition was a speed trial intended for all powered aircraft over a distance of 200 kilometres, to be flown as an outward leg of 100 km followed by a return to the starting point.<ref>[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6551284g/f7.image.r=Deutsch%20de%20la%20Meurthe Bulletin Officiel de l'Aėro-Club de France] [[l'Aėrophile]], March 1906, p.71</ref> The flight had to be made between 1 March and 31 October, and the performance was recognized only if the previous best performance was surpassed by at least 10%. A bonus of 20,000 [[French franc|francs]] was awarded each year for the best performance that had remained unsurpassed for eight months. The Coupe (cup), an objet d'art valued at 10,000 francs, was to be given to the first aircraft builder who won three consecutive competitions.<ref name=flight1919>{{cite |journal=Flight |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201366.html |title=Coupe Henry Deutsch de l a Meurthe |volume=XI |number=564|date=16 October 1919 |page= 1368}}</ref> ===1912 competition=== Despite the substantial prize being offered, it took six years to attract participants. On 12 April 1912, [[Maurice Tabuteau]] piloting a 50 hp [[Gnome et Rhône|Gnome]]-powered [[Morane-Saulnier]] monoplane flew the circuit in 1 h 47 min 48 s, despite persistent navigation problems caused by fog. On 1 May 1912 Parisian Emmanuel Hélen completed the course at {{convert|119.532|kph|mph|abbr=on}} flying a 70 hp Gnome-powered [[Nieuport]] monoplane. Since no other pilot bettered this performance by more than 10% before 31 October 1912, Hélen became the first holder of the Coupe.<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200317.html Flight, 5 May 1921, p. 317]</ref>
===1913 competition=== On 27 October 1913 [[Eugène Gilbert]] gained first place in the second competition for the Coupe, covering the course at an average speed of {{convert|154.38|km/h|mph|abbr=on}} in a 160 h.p. Gnome-powered [[Deperdussin Monocoque]].
===1919/1920 competition=== [[File:Nieuport-Delage 29V racer.jpg|thumb|Nieuport-Delage NiD.29V racer]] The competition was interrupted by the [[World War I|First World War]], but on 13 October 1919 it resumed using the same course, but the competition was now open for the entire year, and the trophy would be definitely kept by the first participant whose time remained unbeaten for eight consecutive months.<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201390.html Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe] ''Flight'' 23 October 1919</ref> Four aeroplanes participated in this trial: a 180 hp [[Hispano-Suiza]]-powered [[Gourdou-Leseurre]] monoplane piloted by Rost, a 300 hp Hispano-Suiza-powered [[Société Pour L'Aviation et ses Dérivés|SPAD]]-Herbemont piloted by [[Joseph Sadi-Lecointe]], a 300 hp Hispano-Suiza-powered Nieuport biplane piloted by [[Bernard Barny de Romanet]], and a 180 hp Le Rhöne-powered Nieuport monoplane designed by engineer Mary, and flown by the Danish pilot [[Leth Jensen]]. Taking off on 13 October 1919, Jensen flew the circuit at an average speed of 200.001 km/h (57 minutes). The next day, Rost reached an average speed of 210 km/h while de Romanet had an aircraft failure. On 15 October, Sadi-Lecointe flew a first circuit at 223 km/h, and then a second lap at 246.9 km/h and thus became the title holder. On 21 October 1919, de Romanet reached an average speed of 268.631 km/h which was insufficient to be homologated, because this performance was less than 110% of Sadi-Lecointe's performance. He followed it the next day with an average speed of 285.600 km/h which did count. <ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1919/1919%20-%201420.html "The Coupe Deutsch"] ''Flight'' 30 October 1919 p1422</ref> Bad weather then stopped the competition, which was resumed just three months later. On 3 January 1920, Sadi-Lecointe, who had in the meanwhile had left [[Blériot-SPAD]] for Nieuport, reached {{convert|266.314|km/h|abbr=on}}<ref>"The Deutsch Cup Contest" ''Flight'' 8 January 1920 p56</ref> with a Hispano-engined [[Nieuport-Delage NiD 29]]V. On 3 August 1920, he became the holder of the Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe, his performance having remained unbeaten.
==Second Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe== In 1920, following the ending of the [[Gordon Bennett Trophy (aeroplanes)|Gordon Bennett Trophy]] competition due to a third consecutive French victory, the Aéro-Club de France decided to organize a new competition to replace it. This was named ''Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe'' to honour [[Henry Deutsch de la Meurthe]], who had died on 24 November 1919; the competition was funded by his family.
It remained a speed competition, but was now to be held on a given date. The competition was to be held as 3 laps of a 100 km (62 mi) circuit, with its start at [[Étampes]] and a turn made at la Marmogne farm at [[Gidy]]. The competition was open for three years and was international, with each country allowed three entrants. A sum of 60,000 francs was to be awarded each year for the best performance, and a cup valued at 20,000 francs given to the winner. In the case of the cup being won outright before the end of the competition, the winner would also received the remaining prize money<ref>{{cite |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200327.html |title=Coupe Henry Deutsch de la Meurthe |journal=Flight |date=12 May 1921 |page=327 |format=pdf |number=645 |volume=XIII)}}</ref>
===1921 competition=== [[File:Nieuport-Delage Sesquiplan.jpg|thumb|Nieuport NiD.41 Sesquiplan]] There were seven participants in this race, which was held on 1 October. No eliminating heats were needed to select from the five French pilot entrants, since Count [[Bernard Barny de Romanet|Bernard de Romanet]] died when the wing fabric of his Lumière-De Monge monoplane<ref group=note>The aircraft could be configured as either a biplane or a monoplane.</ref> detached at high speed during the elimination trials on 23 September, and at the last moment [[Hanriot (aircraft company)|Hanriot]] withdrew their entrant, the Hanriot HD.22. This was a metal monoplane with retractable landing gear expressly built for the race, and which had been intended to be piloted by Rost. Nieuport entered two [[Nieuport-Delage NiD 29|Nieuport NiD.29V]]s piloted by Sadi-Lecointe and Ferdinand Lasne, and a [[Nieuport-Delage Sesquiplan|NiD.41 Sesquiplan]] was entrusted to Georges Kirsch. A 700 hp Fiat-powered [[Fiat Aviazione|Fiat]] biplane piloted by [[Francesco Brack Papa]] represented Italy, and British pilot Herbert James flew a 450 hp [[Napier Lion]]-powered [[Nieuport Nighthawk|Gloster Mars I]] (G-EAXZ).<ref name=flight1921>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1921/1921%20-%200650.html The Coupe de Deutsch de la Meurthe] ''Flight'', 29 September 1921, pp. 650-651]</ref><ref>Lewis 1971, pp. 119-120</ref> A broken propeller forced Sadi-Lecointe to make a forced landing in a beet field at Cernonville, injuring an eye and both legs in the process. The wing fabric of James' aeroplane was torn away, and he had to make a forced landing. Brach Papa established a new Italian speed record, but the engine exploded before the finish. Thus, only two Nieuport pilots were left to finish the race, Georges Kirsch winning with a speed of 282.75 km/h (a new world speed record for a distance of 300 km); Fernand Lasne's speed was 259.03 km/h.{{cn|date=September 2015}}
===1922 competition=== The 1921 circuit remained unchanged for the 1922 competition, which was held on 30 September. Nieuport-Astra<ref group=note>Nieuport having taken over the [[Société Astra]] by this point</ref> entered a Nieuport NiD.29V piloted by Lasne and the sesquiplane piloted by Sadi-Lecointe, [[Jean Casale]] was piloting a Blériot-SPAD S.58, a design based on the [[Blériot-SPAD S.41|S.41 fighter]]. Fiat and Gloster were presenting the same machines and pilots as the preceding year. Assigned to their factory pilot Berthelin, who was new to this competition, the NiD.41 was retired at the last moment. The [[tailless aircraft|tailless]] Simplex aircraft which was supposed to be piloted by [[Georges Madon]] had an accident during its tests, and [[Charles Nungesser]] was absent.<ref name=flight1922>{{cite |url=https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1922/1922%20-%200573.html |title=The race for the Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe |journal= Flight |date=5 October 1922 |pages=573-576}}</ref><ref>Lewis 1971, p. 129</ref> In his Nieuport sesquiplane named ''Eugène Gilbert'' (race number 5), Sadi-Lecointe covered the first 100 km at an average speed of 325 km/h (a new closed circuit speed record), but a spark plug popped out of its cylinder and passed through the engine cowling as he was turning around the airport pylon. The pilot was therefore forced to land, and the airplane hit a gutter which turned the aircraft on its back without injuring the pilot. James lost his maps during his flight and unable to find the turning point returned to the start. Jean Casale's SPAD S.58 ''Louis Blériot'' (race no.3) was victim of a radiator leak, and made a forced landing at Étampes and was unable to finish the race, as was also the case for Brack-Papa's [[Fiat B.R.|Fiat R.700]] which had a fuel pump failure.{{cn|date=September 2015}} The first lap made by the Italian pilot at 288 km/h (179 mph) was not homologated since the aircraft had flown behind the time-keepers at the starting point, but he was offered a second attempt. Brack-Papa started a second time but retired when he realized he would not be able to beat Lasne, ) who won the competition with an average speed of 289.90 km/h.<ref name=flight1922/>
==Third Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe== In 1931 Suzanne Deutsch de la Meurthe initiated a new competition for the Coupe, which was contested for the first time on 29 May 1933. The trial was to be run in two 1,000 km stages separated by a 90 minutes refuelling stop, and was limited to aircraft with an engine capacity of less than eight litres. The starting point of the race was still at Étampes. Suzanne Deutsch de la Meurthe was offering one million Francs, and the Ministère de l'Air (Air Ministry) offered another three million.<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1932/1932%20-%200422.html Flight, 6 May 1932, p. 390]</ref> ===1933 competition=== [[File:Potez 53 Musee du Bourget P1010709.JPG|thumb|A Potez 53]] On 24 May 1933 Captain [[Ludovic Arrachart]] was killed when his [[Caudron C.362|Caudron C.360]] (race no.11) crashed due to engine failure at Maisons near [[Chartres]] while he was training for the competition.<ref name>{{cite journal|journal=[[l'Aérophile]]|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65535525/f6.image.r=caudron|date=June 1933|page=166|title=La Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe}}</ref> The event was won by Georges Détré flying a [[Potez 53]] powered by a Potez 9B radial engine developing barely 310 hp at full power at a speed of {{convert|322.81|kph|mph}}, beating Raymond Delmotte's Caudron C.362 (race no.6) with a speed of {{convert|291.12|kph|mph}}, and also beating the only foreign competitor, [[Nick Comper]] flying [[Comper Swift]] ''G-ABWW'' {{convert|239.58|kph|mph}}.<ref>Lewis 1971, p.251</ref> A third French competitor, test pilot Lemoine also flying a Potez 53, was forced to abandon the race.<ref name=flight1934-510>[https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1934/1934%20-%200510.html Flight, 24 May 1934, pp. 510-511]</ref>
===1934 competition=== [[File:Caudron 460 Le Bourget 2009.jpg|thumb|A Caudron C.460 replica]] [[File:GMars.jpg|thumb|Gloster Mars I (G-EAXZ)]] On 27 May 1934, the race was a duel between the Caudron pilots, the [[Caudron]] firm presenting two racing aircraft designed by [[Marcel Riffard]]. [[Maurice Arnoux]] won with a C.450 at a speed of 388.97 km/h overtaking Louis Massotte's [[Régnier Motor Company|Regnier]]-engined (and sponsored) C.366 (360.72 km/h) and Albert Monville's Renault-engined [[Caudron C.460]] (341.04 km/h). Nick Comper flew the [[Comper Streak]] (G-ACNC), but retired on the 6th lap of the afternoon session as problem with the undercarriage limited his speed. Georges Detre flying a [[Potez 53]]-2 retired after problems with his engine oil supply. The [[Potez 53]]-3 had problems with its variable pitch propeller and was unable to start for the second section,<ref>Lewis 1971, p. 259</ref><ref name=flight1934-510/><ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/flightpdfarchive/view/1933/1933%20-%200976.html Flight, 9 Nov 1933, p. 976]</ref><ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1934/1934%20-%200480.html Flight, 17 May 1934, pp. 476, 480-481]</ref><ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1934/1934%20-%200531.html Flight, 31 May 1934, pp. 531-532]</ref>
===1935 competition=== The 1935 race was arguably the most exciting{{cn|date=September 2015}} competition of them all, and was the consecration of the Caudron-Renault racers. Eight pilots were registered for this event, but the [[Nennig C-3]] (race no.4) of [[Guy Bart]] was not ready, and the Régnier Martinet, a modified Caudron C.366, (race no.2) was damaged during its tests. Two Caudron C.560s were supposed to participate (race no.1 and 3), but were not ready. They were thus replaced by a [[Caudron C.430]] and a C.450 with the same race numbers.<ref name=flight1935>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1935/1935%20-%201324.html "A Family Affair"] ''Flight'', 30 May 1935, p. 600</ref>
The course was over 100 km (62 miles), from [[Etampes]] aerodrome to [[Chartres]] [[Boncé|Bonce]] and back. The race itself was in two stages, each of 1,000 km (625 miles).
Charles Franco was the first to take off in Caudron C.430 (race no.1), but abandoned the race on the fourth lap as he was clearly out-classed by the other aircraft. It was followed by the Caudron C.460s of [[Yves Lacombe]] (race no.5), [[Raymond Delmotte]] (Caudron's chief pilot) (race no.8 ), and [[Maurice Arnoux]] (race no.6) respectively, this last entrant having to quit the race after seven laps, having run out of oil after a high-speed lap at {{convert|469|km/h|abbr=on}}. [[Albert Monville]]'s Caudron C.450 (race no.3) was the last to take off. Only three aircraft qualified for the second part of the race, which was held during rain showers. Raymond Delmotte won, ahead of Yves Lacombe and Maurice Arnoux, flying the aircraft previously flown by Albert Monville .<ref name=flight1935/>
==Fourth Coupe Deutsch de la Meurthe== On 13 September 1936, a last competition was organized, in which two [[Caudron C.461]]s, one Caudron C.450 and two [[Caudron C.560]]s took part. Yves Lacombe won this race with a speed of only {{convert|389.462|km/h|abbr=on}}, overtaking Maurice Arnoux timed at {{convert|369.59|km/h|abbr=on}}, a performance barely superior to what had been established in 1934, probably because of bad engine tuning in a competition presenting no real challenge for the engine and aircraft manufacturers.<ref>[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1936/1936%20-%202782.html ''Flight'', 15 October 1936, p. 387]</ref>{{failed verification|reason=source does not mention anything save Lacombe won|date=September 2015}}

{{Infobox film | name = Disclosure | image = Disclosure ver2.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Barry Levinson]] | producer = {{ubl|[[Michael Crichton]]|Barry Levinson}} | based on = {{basedon|''[[Disclosure (novel)|Disclosure]]''|Michael Crichton}} | writer = Paul Attanasio | starring = {{ubl|[[Michael Douglas]]|[[Demi Moore]]|[[Donald Sutherland]]|[[Caroline Goodall]]|[[Dennis Miller]]}} | music = [[Ennio Morricone]] | cinematography = [[Tony Pierce-Roberts]] | editing = [[Stu Linder]] | distributor = [[Warner Bros.]] | released = {{Film date|1994|12|09}} | runtime = 128 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $55 million<ref name="boxofficemojo.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=disclosure.htm|title=Disclosure (1994) - Box Office Mojo|author=|date=|website=www.boxofficemojo.com|accessdate=4 October 2018}}</ref> | gross = $214 million<ref name="boxofficemojo.com" /> }} '''''Disclosure''''' is a 1994 American [[erotic thriller]] film directed by [[Barry Levinson]], starring [[Michael Douglas]] and [[Demi Moore]]. It is based on [[Michael Crichton]]'s [[Disclosure (novel)|novel of the same name]].<ref>{{cite news|title= Douglas, Moore Star in Adaptation of Crichton's Novel on Harassment Reversal|work= The Los Angeles Times|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1994-12-09/entertainment/ca-14310_1_michael-crichton|accessdate=2010-10-24}}</ref> The cast also includes [[Donald Sutherland]], [[Rosemary Forsyth]] and [[Dennis Miller]]. The film is a combination thriller and slight mystery in an office setting within the computer industry in the mid-1990s. The main focus of the story, from which the film and book take their titles, is the issue of [[sexual harassment]] and its power structure.
==Plot== Bob Garvin, a technology company founder, plans to retire when his company [[mergers and acquisitions|merges]] with a larger company. Production line manager Tom Sanders expects to be promoted to run the [[CD-ROM]] division. Instead, Meredith Johnson, a former girlfriend of Tom's, is promoted to the post. Meredith calls Tom into her office to discuss some operations, then sexually forces herself onto him. He initially reciprocates, then rebuffs her. Meredith, angry, screams a threat for spurning her.
The next day, Meredith has filed a [[sexual harassment]] complaint against Tom with legal counsel Philip Blackburn. To save the merger from a scandal, DigiCom officials demand that Tom accept reassignment to another location. Otherwise, he will lose his stock options in the new company. His career will be ruined, however, as the other location is scheduled for sale after the merger, leaving Tom jobless.
Tom receives an anonymous e-mail from, "A Friend", that directs him to Seattle attorney Catherine Alvarez, who specializes in sexual harassment cases. Tom decides to sue DigiCom, alleging that it was Meredith who harassed him. The initial mediation goes badly for Tom as a tearful Meredith blames him.
Garvin proposes that if Tom drops the matter, he will not have to transfer, causing Tom to suspect that Meredith's accusations are vulnerable. Tom remembers mis-dialing a number on his cell phone during the encounter with Meredith but not hanging up. This inadvertently left a recording of the incident on a colleague's voicemail. Tom plays the recording at the next meeting and discredits Meredith. DigiCom agrees to a settlement calling for Meredith to quietly be eased out following the merger.
As Tom celebrates his apparent victory, he receives another e-mail from "A Friend" warning that all is not what it seems. Tom overhears Meredith telling Philip that even though the harassment accusation attempt failed, they will make Tom look incompetent at the next morning's merger conference. If the problems with the CD-ROMs are shown as coming from the production line, which is under Tom's responsibility, he can be fired for cause.
Tom attempts to look for clues in the company database, but his access privileges have been revoked. He remembers that the merging company's executives have a [[virtual reality]] demonstration machine that has access to company databases. As he gets into DigiCom's files, he sees Meredith is deleting them. Tom receives a call from a Malaysian colleague who gets Tom copies of incriminating memos and videos. They show that Meredith and the head of operations in Malyasia were conspiring to change the plans and specifications that Tom implemented to sabotage the CD-ROMs in order to harm Tom's career.
When Tom makes his presentation at the conference and Meredith brings up the production problems, he shows the memos and a video exposing her involvement in causing defects with the hardware. Meredith says that Tom is mounting a last-ditch effort of revenge on her.
Meredith is fired by Garvin who passes over Tom and names Stephanie Kaplan to the post. Tom is disappointed but pleased that his colleague. Tom asks Stephanie's son, Spencer, if he knows "A Friend". Spencer says he is Arthur Friend's research assistant at the University of Washington. Tom realizes that Spencer accessed Friend's office computer, meaning Stephanie (via her son) is likely the "friend" who helped him. Satisfied, Tom returns to his position at the production division.
==Cast== {{div col}} * [[Michael Douglas]] as Tom Sanders * [[Demi Moore]] as Meredith Johnson * [[Donald Sutherland]] as Bob Garvin * [[Caroline Goodall]] as Susan Hendler * [[Roma Maffia]] as Catherine Alvarez * [[Dylan Baker]] as Philip Blackburn * [[Rosemary Forsyth]] as Stephanie Kaplan * [[Dennis Miller]] as Mark Lewyn * [[Suzie Plakson]] as Mary Anne Hunter * [[Nicholas Sadler]] as Don Cherry * [[Jacqueline Kim]] as Cindy Chang * [[Kate Williamson]] as Judge Barbara Murphy * [[Donal Logue]] as Chance Geer * [[Farrah Forke]] as Adele Lewyn * [[Allan Rich]] as Ben Heller {{div col end}}
==Production== [[Michael Crichton]] sold the movie rights for $1 million before the novel was published. [[Miloš Forman]] was originally attached to direct but left due to creative differences with Crichton. [[Barry Levinson]] and [[Alan J. Pakula]] were in contention to take the helm and Levinson was hired.
[[Annette Bening]] was originally set to play Meredith until she became pregnant and soon dropped out. [[Geena Davis]] and [[Michelle Pfeiffer]] were then considered before Levinson decided to cast [[Demi Moore]]. Crichton wrote the character Mark Lewyn for the film specifically with [[Dennis Miller]] in mind. The character from the book was somewhat modified for the screenplay to fit Miller's personality.
The virtual reality corridor sequence was designed by [[Industrial Light & Magic]].<ref name="Notes">''Disclosure'' DVD (2000). Production notes. [[Warner Home Video]].</ref>
==Filming locations== The movie was filmed in and around [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]. The fictional corporation DigiCom is located in [[Pioneer Square, Seattle|Pioneer Square]], on a set which was constructed for the film. Production designer Neil Spisak said, "DigiCom needed to have a hard edge to it, with lots of glass and a modern look juxtaposed against the old red brick which is indigenous to the Pioneer Square area of Seattle. Barry liked the idea of using glass so that wherever you looked you'd see workers in their offices or stopping to chat. This seemed to fit the ominous sense that Barry was looking for, a sort of ''[[Rear Window]]'' effect, where you're looking across at people in their private spaces."<ref name="Notes"/>
Also shown are the [[Washington State Ferries]] because Douglas' character lives on [[Bainbridge Island]]. Other locations include [[Washington Park Arboretum]], [[Volunteer Park (Seattle)|Volunteer Park]], the [[Four Seasons Hotel]] on University St., [[Pike Place Market]] and [[Smith Tower]] (Alvarez's law office).<ref>http://www.seattle.gov/filmoffice/filmmap.htm</ref> The director of photography was British cinematographer [[Tony Pierce-Roberts]].
==Soundtrack== The score of ''Disclosure'' was composed, orchestrated and conducted by [[Ennio Morricone]]. ''Original Motion Picture Soundtrack from the Film Disclosure'' was released by [[Virgin Records]] on January 24, 1995.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Disclosure-1994-Film-Ennio-Morricone/dp/B000000W7D|title=Amazon.com: Disclosure (1994 Film): Music|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|accessdate=2014-04-25}}</ref>
===Track listing=== # "Serene Family" − 4:11 # "An Unusual Approach" − 7:07 # "With Energy and Decision" − 2:07 # "Virtual Reality" − 6:24 # "Preparation and Victory" − 4:04 # "Disclosure" − 0:49 # "Sad Family" − 1:29 # "Unemployed!" − 1:10 # "Sex and Computers" − 2:50 # "Computers and Work" − 2:00 # "Sex and Power" − 2:33 # "First [[Passacaglia]]" − 4:21 # "Second Passacaglia" − 1:41 # "Third Passacaglia" − 4:33 # "Sex, Power and Computers" − 4:23<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/disclosure-original-soundtrack-mw0000124912|title=Disclosure [Original Soundtrack] - Ennio Morricone|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|accessdate=2014-04-25}}</ref>
==Reception== Critic [[Roger Ebert]] called the film "basically a launch pad for sex scenes" and gave it only two stars out of a possible four. On the other hand, Ian Nathan of ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]'' magazine called it "genuinely gripping", further stating that "[[Demi Moore]] makes an awesome [[femme fatale]]." It currently has a rating of 58% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] based on 59 reviews.
''Disclosure'' was a soaring financial success, grossing $214 million worldwide ($83 million in U.S. and Canadian ticket sales and $131 million in other territories), against a budget of about $55 million.<ref>{{cite news|title= Weekend Box Office Disclosure' Is Hot on a Slow Weekend |work= [[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1994-12-13/entertainment/ca-8547_1_weekend-box-office|accessdate=2010-11-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= 'Disclosure' Edges Out 'Santa' at the Box Office Movies: Much-hyped sexual-harassment drama pushes aside the Tim Allen heavyweight. |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|url= http://articles.latimes.com/1994-12-12/entertainment/ca-8096_1_tim-allen|accessdate=2010-11-12}}</ref> It became one of director [[Barry Levinson]]'s most successful films after his initial successes with ''[[Good Morning, Vietnam]]'' and ''[[Rain Man]]''.
In a review, [[Nathan Rabin]] described the film as superior to its source novel: "If there were an Academy Award for Best Screen Adaptation Of A Screamingly Awful, Viciously Sexist Novel, ''Disclosure'' would triumph. The film takes a preachy, disingenuous, and poorly written [[wikt:jeremiad|jeremiad]] against sexually aggressive women and turns it into a sleek, sexy, and only moderately sexist piece of Hollywood entertainment."<ref name="nr">[http://thedissolve.com/features/forgotbusters/92-forgotbusters-disclosure/ Disclosure] Nathan Rabin, ''The Dissolve'', August 16, 2013. Retrieved February 15, 2014.</ref> Rabin also argued, however, that ultimately the film's cast and crew could only "elevate the film to the level of sleek mediocrity."<ref name="nr"/>
==See also== * ''[[Aitraaz]]'', Bollywood remake of ''Disclosure'' * ''[[Inkaar (2013 film)|Inkaar]]'' [[Inkaar (2013 film)|(2013 film)]], a Hindi film with a similar plot * ''[[Indira Vizha]]'', a [[Tamil language|Tamil]] film adaptation

{{short description|International minimum standard for a person professionally leading a group of certified recreational divers}} '''Dive leader''' describes the minimum requirements for dive leader training and certification for [[Recreational diving|recreational scuba divers]] in international standard ISO 24801-3 <ref name=" ISO24801-3" /> and the equivalent European Standard EN 14153-3. Various organizations offer training that meets the requirements of the dive leader standard.
Scuba dive leaders are considered competent to plan, organise and conduct dives and to lead other recreational divers on open water dives, and for specialised recreational scuba diving activities for which they have been trained. They are also considered competent to conduct emergency procedures associated with these activities and the relevant diving environment. They may require orientation for unfamiliar local environmental conditions. Additional specialised training and experience is required to lead divers on more demanding dives.<ref name="EUF certification" />
The term is also used by BSAC for a specific certification.<ref name="BSAC dive leader"/>
==Scope of the standard== International standard ISO 24801-3 includes:<ref name=" ISO24801-3" /> *Prerequisites for training, including age and health requirements, *Required theoretical knowledge regarding scuba and basic diving equipment, the basic physics of diving, decompression management and dive planning, medical and psychological problems related to diving, the diving environment and the use of nitrox breathing gases, *Required scuba skills in confined and open water, *Practical training parameters, *Evaluation of knowledge and practical skills.
==Training according to ISO 24801-3== Diver qualifications which comply with ISO 24801-3
==Medical fitness to dive== {{main|Fitness to dive}} Before initial diver training and thereafter at regular intervals, a diver should undergo a [[fitness to dive]] examination by a diving doctor. This may be considered more important for a dive leader who has a duty of care to their clients. In some countries, such an examination is required by law and it is a prerequisite for any training in many diving schools.

<ref name=" ISO24801-3">{{cite web |url=https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:std:iso:24801:-3:ed-2:v1:en|last=Staff|title=Recreational diving services — Requirements for the training of recreational scuba divers — Part 3: Level 3 — Dive leader (ISO 24801-3:2014) |publisher=[[International Standards Organisation|ISO]] |access-date=2015-04-29}}</ref>
<ref name="EUF certification">{{cite web|url=http://www.euf-certification.org/euf-certification/training-organisations/relevant-standards/competencies-and-qualifications/ |last=Staff|publisher=European Underwater Federation (EUF)|work=EUF Certification|title=Competencies and qualifications of recreational scuba divers Level 1-3|accessdate=10 August 2017}}</ref>
<ref name="BSAC dive leader">{{cite web|url=https://www.bsac.com/page.asp?section=3306|last=staff|title=Diver grade training: Dive leader|work=|accessdate=10 August 2017}}</ref>
}}

{{coord|37|40|24.66|N|122|4|52.72|W|region:US|display=title}} [[File:Downtownhaywardcitycenter.jpg|thumb|Downtown Hayward, looking south on Foothill Boulevard, with the [[City Center Building]] (left)]] '''Downtown Hayward''' is the original and current [[central business district]] of [[Hayward, California]], [[United States]], and is home to the current [[Hayward City Hall]], along with the two previous city halls, [[Alex Giualini Plaza]] and the [[City Center Building]]. The [[Hayward Fault]] runs through the area, and is the cause of the two previous city halls being taken out of use.
The boundaries are Third Street to the east, Grand Street and [[Hayward (BART station)|Hayward BART]] to the west, [[California State Route 92|Jackson Street]] and E Street to the south, and City Center Drive/Hazel Avenue to the north.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hayward-ca.gov/CITY-GOVERNMENT/SPECIAL-PROJECTS-&-STUDIES/dpu/img/plan_area.JPG |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-03-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130907122147/http://www.hayward-ca.gov/CITY-GOVERNMENT/SPECIAL-PROJECTS-%26-STUDIES/dpu/img/plan_area.JPG |archivedate=2013-09-07 |df= }}</ref> Foothill Boulevard was known as "The Golden Strip", a retail business corridor that was built in the 1950s, and housed [[The Emporium, San Francisco|Capwell's]] and [[I. Magnin]] department stores. The street lost businesses after the opening of [[Southland Mall (Hayward, California)|Southland Mall]] in 1964.<ref name="insidebayarea1">{{cite web|url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/localnews/ci_19616418 |title=Foothill Boulevard gateway getting face-lift in Hayward |publisher=Inside Bay Area |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> Parks include Newman Park and The Julio Bras Portuguese Park. [[San Lorenzo Creek]] runs through downtown. The Hayward Public Library is located there. "Hayward City Center" a mall and building complex located at the northern end of downtown, contains the [[City Center Building]], which served as the city's second city hall from 1969 to 1991, and is now an abandoned 11 story building, Hayward's tallest building, formerly the second tallest prior to [[California State University, East Bay]]'s [[Warren Hall]] demolition in 2013. The City Center complex previously contained the now demolished [[Centennial Hall Convention Center]]. The bankrupt [[Mervyns]] department store chain's large [[Mervyns Building|former headquarters]] is across the street from the City Center mall. The [[Hayward Area Historical Society]] operates a museum downtown, which relocated and re-opened June 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haywardareahistory.org/ |title=Hayward Area Historical Society|publisher=Haywardareahistory.org|accessdate=2010-12-25}}</ref> The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] operates a resident agency in downtown Hayward.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fbi.gov/contact-us/field/resident-agencies/hayward-resident-agency|title=FBI — Hayward Resident Agency|publisher=Fbi.gov|accessdate=2010-12-25|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111015031801/http://www.fbi.gov/contact-us/field/resident-agencies/hayward-resident-agency|archivedate=2011-10-15|df=}}</ref> The Hayward Art Council, founded in 1975, operates the Sun Gallery downtown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sungallery.org/about.html |title=About Sun Gallery |publisher=Sungallery.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623010709/http://www.sungallery.org/about.html |archivedate=2012-06-23 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sungallery.org/contact.html |title=Contact Information and Gallery Location |publisher=Sungallery.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623001725/http://www.sungallery.org/contact.html |archivedate=2012-06-23 |df= }}</ref> The [[Independent Order of Odd Fellows]] building on B Street is one of Hayward's oldest buildings, and was built in 1868.<ref>{{cite web|last=Parr |first=Rebecca |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/news/ci_21142759/hometown-hero-mr-hayward-frank-goulart-historian-and |title=Hometown Hero: 'Mr. Hayward' Frank Goulart, a historian and activist - San Jose Mercury News |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> The Hayward [[Memorials and services for the September 11 attacks|9/11 Memorial]] was dedicated May 30, 2016, to the first responders who died in 9/11, and to the city's own fallen first responders, and the city's fallen soldiers.<ref>[http://www.eastbaytimes.com/breaking-news/ci_29913348/hayward-9-11-memorial-nears-completion]</ref>
==Cinema Place== Cinema Place is a {{convert|12000|sqft|m2}} entertainment and shopping center, comprising a single structure, which opened October 24, 2008.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.blakehunt.com/cinema_place.php |title=Blake Hunt Ventures, Inc |publisher=Blakehunt.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120723064035/http://www.blakehunt.com/cinema_place.php |archivedate=2012-07-23 |df= }}</ref> Directly adjacent to the center is a large city run parking garage. The City of Hayward has commissioned 3 large murals, designed by Hayward artist Andrew Kong Knight, decorating the exterior of the garage, featuring scenes from Hollywood and Hayward, which are being executed in 2011.<ref name="andrewkongknight1">{{cite web|url=http://www.andrewkongknight.com/art/murals/index.html|title=Public Art Mural Projects|publisher=Andrewkongknight.com|accessdate=2012-10-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320154900/http://www.andrewkongknight.com/art/murals/index.html|archivedate=2012-03-20|df=}}</ref> An additional mural by Knight is found at the northern end of The Hayward Strip.<ref name="andrewkongknight1"/><ref>{{cite web|author=: Andrew 380 friends |url=http://sanfrancisco.tribe.net/event/Hayward-Gateway-Mural-by-Andrew-Kong-Knight-Celebration-Party-Saturday-May-1-2010/san-francisco-ca/d62ae6c5-d941-4c35-809b-77227d15483e |title=Hayward Gateway Mural by Andrew Kong Knight ~ Celebration Party Saturday, May 1, 2010 - Hayward / Castro Valley - tribe.net |publisher=Sanfrancisco.tribe.net |date=2010-05-01 |accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref> Hayward's Public Mural Art Program has won a Helen Putnam Award of Excellence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helenputnam.org/winners_2011.php |title=Helen Putnam Award of Excellence |publisher=Helenputnam.org |date=2012-04-12 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
The [[Anchor store|main tenant]] is a [[Century Theatres|Century Theatre]] multiplex, which is Hayward's lone movie theater since [[Mann Theatres|Mann]]'s Festival Cinemas closed in 2003. In 2011, the Hayward Art Council opened a gallery on the ground floor of the center, in a storefront that has remained unused since the center's opening.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haywardarts.org/pages/events.html |title=About Hayward Arts Council |publisher=Haywardarts.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibabuzz.com/hayword/2011/01/19/cinema-place-gallery-opening-downtown/ |title=Cinema Place Gallery opening downtown - The HayWord |publisher=Ibabuzz.com |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref>
[[File:Allsaintscatholicchurchhayward.jpg|thumb|All Saints Catholic Church]]
==Other businesses== The Total Package Salon, under new ownership and new management, is located at 1122 B St. The salon is ran by celebrity stylists and women who have worked in the movie beauty industry. Truly a staple of Downtown Hayward. The [[Green Shutter Hotel]], a [[California Historical Landmark]], is located downtown. [[Buffalo Bill's Brewery]], founded in 1983 by photographer [[Bill Owens (photographer)|Bill Owens]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gregkucera.com/owens.htm |title=Bill Owens | Greg Kucera Gallery | Seattle |publisher=Gregkucera.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref><ref>[http://www.buffalobillsbrewery.com/bbb_about.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100801070813/http://www.buffalobillsbrewery.com/bbb_about.htm |date=August 1, 2010 }}</ref> is one of the first [[brewpub]]s to open in California since [[Prohibition in the United States|Prohibition]], after legislation passed in 1982 legalizing brewpubs again.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eastbayexpress.com/92510/archives/2007/09/13/tom-bates-beer-savior|title= ''Tom Bates: Beer Savior''|publisher= East Bay Express|date= September 13, 2007|accessdate=2012-10-24}}</ref> The ''[[Daily Review]]'' newspaper operated from downtown, until its closure in 2016.
==Services== The All Saints Catholic Church is located downtown.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sean |first=Michael |url=http://ncronline.org/news/faith-parish/pastor-dynamic-parish-shows-benefits-viable-alternative-structure |title=Dynamic California parish shows benefits of an alternative structure | National Catholic Reporter |publisher=Ncronline.org |date=2014-01-02 |accessdate=2014-03-01}}</ref> It operates the [[Mount Saint Joseph Cemetery (Hayward, California)|Mount Saint Joseph Cemetery]]. The Hayward Veterans' Memorial Building, built in 1932, is adjacent to the old City Hall building, and is available for public events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.acgov.org/veterans/hayward/ |title=Hayward - Veterans' Memorial Building - Alameda County |publisher=Acgov.org |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref> The Hayward Area Historical Society opened a new museum, galleries, and an events venue in June 2014.<ref name="mercurynews.com">{{cite web|author=Rebecca ParrThe Daily Review |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_22410916/foothill-boulevard-hayward-undergoing-transformation |title=Foothill Boulevard in Hayward undergoing transformation - San Jose Mercury News |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-01}}</ref>
==Road improvements== [[File:Hayward 9 11 memorial 1.jpg|thumb|left|Hayward 9/11 Memorial]] The [[Hayward, California#Transportation|Route 238 Corridor Improvement Project]] broke ground July 2010, with an expected completion date in 2013. It will include undergrounding of telephone wires, and extensive landscaping, bringing parks and improved traffic flow to the downtown region. A one-way traffic loop for sections of A Street, Foothill Boulevard and Mission Boulevard went into effect March 15, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|author=Rebecca ParrThe Daily Review |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_22623941/hayward-begin-one-way-downtown-traffic-loop-march |title=Hayward to begin one-way downtown traffic loop March 15 - San Jose Mercury News |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-03-01}}</ref> The Foothill Boulevard business district is also scheduled to receive a $2.85 million face-lift, partly through $1.1 million in loans, improving the storefront facades and other amenities. New businesses opening include a [[microdistillery]] to be operated by Buffalo Bill's Brewery.<ref name="insidebayarea1"/><ref name="mercurynews.com"/>
[[File:Big Mike, Muffler Man, Hayward, California.jpg|thumb|"Big Mike", [[Muffler Men|"Muffler Man"]], long term fixture on Mission Boulevard (removed in 2011, moved to south Hayward in 2013)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tip/3208 |title=Hayward, CA - Muffler Man - Sold, Moved |publisher=Roadsideamerica.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bellplastics.com/ |title=Custom Plastic Fabrication |publisher=Bell Plastics |date= |accessdate=2014-03-01}}</ref>]]
